newsitem.title: DENMARK: More Danish share rises seen dependent on U.S..
newsitem.headline: More Danish share rises seen dependent on U.S..

text.p: Danish share prices closed higher on Tuesday, bolstered by a stronger pound sterling following the new London government's move to make the Bank of England more independent, with dealers foreseeing further rises ahead dependent on Wall Street trends.
"Leading banks, Moeller and Berendsen climbed on the firmer pound, the market should remain positive with more gains if the U.S. performs well overnight," one dealer said.
The KFX top-20 index closed 2.41 point up at 160.04 in overall bourse turnover of 890 million crowns.
The KFX June future climbed 1.40 point to 159.70 with 455 contracts each worth 100,000 crowns traded.
Den Danske Bank closed 11 crowns up at 600, Unidanmark put on three to finish at 336, while Moeller's D/S 1912 ended 8,500 up at 222,000 and twin D/S Svendborg put on 15,500 to 320,000.

Berendsen finished 10 crowns up at 826, also aided by the bullish pound. SAS closed unchanged at 70 crowns, but the airline announced a swing into the red in 1997's first quarter after the Copenhagen bourse had closed. --Chris Follett, Copenhagen newsroom +45-33-969652
